message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about how glaciers leave evidence of their movement. When a glacier moves through an area, it leaves distinct marks on the nearby stone and landforms, such as scratches, grooves, and piles of rocks. Scientists can examine these features to determine if a glacier passed through an area in the past. Options (A), (B), and (C) are unrelated to the evidence of glacier movement and are incorrect.

This question requires some basic knowledge about how glaciers leave behind evidence of their movement. Glaciers leave distinct patterns and marks on the land as they move, and scientists can study these marks to determine if a glacier passed through an area in the past. By glancing at nearby stones, scientists can look for characteristic scratches, grooves, and other markings left by the glacier. Option (A) is incorrect because looking at the moon has no relation to determining if a glacier moved through an area. Option (B) is unrelated to glaciers. Option (C) is also unrelated to glaciers and their movement.

This question requires some basic knowledge about glacial movement and how scientists study geological formations. When a glacier moves through an area, it leaves behind distinct patterns and features on nearby rocks and landforms. These patterns, such as scratches and grooves, can be observed and studied by scientists to determine that a glacier had passed through the area. Option (A) is unrelated to glacial movement. Option (B) and (C) are also unrelated as they do not provide any information about past glacial activity.

This question requires basic knowledge about how scientists determine the presence of a glacier in an area. When a glacier moves through an area, it leaves behind distinct geological features, such as scratches and grooves on rocks, known as glacial striations. These features can be observed by scientists when they glance at nearby stone, helping them determine that a glacier has indeed passed through the area. Options (A), (B), and (C) are unrelated to the presence of a glacier and do not provide any evidence for its movement.
